image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: (Father of Charles J. Luken), a Representative from Ohio; born in Cincinnati, Hamilton County, July 9, 1925; graduated from Purcell High School, 1942; A.B., Xavier University, Cincinnati, 1947; attended Bowling Green State University, Toledo, Ohio, 1943-1944; LL.B., Salmon P. Chase Law School, Cincinnati, 1950; served in the United States Marine Corps, 1943-1945, with rank of first lieutenant; admitted to the Ohio bar in 1950 and commenced practice in Cincinnati; city solicitor, city of Deer Park for four terms, 1955-1961; Federal district attorney, 1961-1964; member, Cincinnati City Council, 1964-1967, 1969-1971, 1973-1974; mayor of Cincinnati, 1971-1972; delegate, Democratic National Conventions, 1964, 1968; elected as a Democrat to the Ninety-third Congress, by special election, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of United States Representative William J. Keating, (March 5, 1974-January 3, 1975); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1974 to the Ninety-fourth Congress; resumed the practice of law; elected to the Ninety-fifth and to the six succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1977-January 3, 1991); was not a candidate for renomination in 1990 to the One Hundred Second Congress; died on January 10, 2018, in Cincinnati, Ohio.

researchRecord.name: 1974-1988, 5 commercials on 2 videoreels, 7 commercials on 4 videocassettes, and 8 commercials on 1 sound tape reel.
researchRecord.description: The commercials were used during Thomas Luken's campaigns for the 1974 and 1988 U.S. congressional elections in District 1 of Ohio, Democratic Party.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication

researchRecord.name: 1952-1972, 5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of former Congressman Thomas A. Luken contain his personal files on issues concerning the City of Cincinnati while he served on City Council and with the United States prosecutor's office. The files contain correspondence, news clippings, and reports on topics such as welfare, poverty, housing, and public transportation.
